meta.title: How Emotionally Intelligent Is Your Child?
meta.description: See where your child shines emotionally — and where they're still growing. A strength-focused look at four key areas of emotional development.
meta.intro: Answer based on what your child does most of the time — not their best day or worst day. Every child develops differently, and there are no bad scores here.
meta.subject: your child
meta.shareCta: See your child's emotional intelligence profile

questions.text: Your child comes home upset after school. When you ask what happened, they say...

options.text: "I don't know!" and runs to their room
"I'm mad" — they name the basic feeling
"I feel sad and kind of angry at the same time"
"I'm frustrated because Jake took my turn and the teacher didn't see it"

questions.text: Your child doesn't get the toy they really wanted for their birthday. What happens?

options.text: Full meltdown — takes a long time to recover
Pouts and sulks for most of the day
Visibly disappointed, might cry, but moves on within a few minutes
Says "I'm really disappointed" but handles it and finds something to enjoy

questions.text: A younger child at the playground falls down and starts crying. Your kid...

options.text: Doesn't notice or walks away
Looks over but keeps playing
Goes over to check on them or tells an adult
Tries to comfort them — "Are you okay? Do you want me to help you up?"

questions.text: Your child is building something with blocks and it keeps falling apart. They...

options.text: Throws it across the room or screams
Gets upset and needs you to calm them down before they'll try again
Asks for help before getting too frustrated
Gets frustrated but tries a different approach on their own

questions.text: When reading a book together, can your child identify how the characters are feeling?

options.text: Rarely — they focus on what's happening, not how people feel
Sometimes — they notice "happy" and "sad"
Often — they pick up on things like "worried" or "embarrassed"
Regularly — they predict emotional reactions and explain why characters feel that way

questions.text: When your child is told they can't have something they want right now...

options.text: Screaming, crying, full tantrum — every time
Usually upset — sometimes can accept it with a lot of explanation
Disappointed but can wait if they know when they'll get it
Handles it most of the time — might negotiate but accepts the answer

questions.text: When someone in the family is visibly sad or stressed, your child...

options.text: Seems unaware — continues what they're doing
Notices something is off but doesn't know what to do
Asks "What's wrong?" or tries to help in some way
Adjusts their behavior — speaks more quietly, brings you something, offers comfort

questions.text: When your child loses a game...

options.text: Major meltdown — crying, accusing others of cheating, wants to quit
Gets upset but calms down with some help from you
Disappointed but can congratulate the winner with a little prompting
Handles it well — might say "good game" or ask to play again

questions.text: When your child is angry, they typically...

options.text: Lash out physically — hitting, throwing, biting
Yell or scream without naming what they're feeling
Say "I'm angry!" or "I'm mad!" — even if loudly
Express what they're angry about and sometimes suggest what would help

questions.text: How does your child handle transitions — leaving the park, turning off screens, switching activities?

options.text: Major resistance every time — tantrums, refusal, bargaining
Hard but getting better — still needs a lot of support
Usually manages with a warning ("5 more minutes")
Transitions fairly smoothly with minimal reminders

high.headline: Rich emotional vocabulary
high.detail: Your child can name a wide range of feelings and describe what's driving them. They distinguish between similar emotions (frustrated vs. angry, nervous vs. scared) and can articulate the cause. This is a genuine strength — emotional literacy is one of the strongest predictors of social success.
high.strength: They have the words to process what they're feeling instead of acting it out

medium.headline: Building their feelings dictionary
medium.detail: Your child can name basic emotions (happy, sad, mad, scared) and is starting to get more nuanced. They don't always have the words in the heat of the moment, but can often reflect on feelings afterward. This is exactly where most kids their age are.
medium.strength: They're developing the language foundation — keep narrating emotions in daily life

low.headline: Feelings are still hard to name
low.detail: Your child experiences big feelings but doesn't yet have the vocabulary to identify or describe them. This often shows up as physical reactions (hitting, shutting down, running away) instead of words. This is very common and completely workable.
low.concern: Try labeling their emotions for them: "It looks like you're feeling frustrated because..." — you're building the dictionary they'll use later

high.headline: Strong self-regulation skills
high.detail: Your child can manage their impulses, handle disappointment, and recover from emotional intensity without extended meltdowns. They're developing the ability to pause between feeling and reacting — which is genuinely impressive at any age.
high.strength: They can feel a big emotion without being completely hijacked by it

medium.headline: Regulation is a work in progress
medium.detail: Your child can sometimes manage their reactions, especially when they're not too tired or hungry. Other times, feelings overwhelm their coping skills and they need your help to co-regulate. This back-and-forth is completely normal — self-regulation develops gradually.
medium.strength: They're showing signs of self-management — consistency and patience will build on this

low.headline: Still learning to manage big reactions
low.detail: When feelings hit, your child gets flooded — meltdowns are intense and recovery takes time. They rely heavily on you to calm down. This isn't a character flaw; their brain's regulation circuitry is still under construction.
low.concern: Focus on co-regulation first: stay calm yourself, narrate what's happening, and trust that your calm is slowly teaching theirs

high.headline: Naturally tuned into others
high.detail: Your child notices other people's emotions and responds with genuine care. They adjust their behavior based on how others are feeling and often try to help without being asked. This is a beautiful strength that reflects deep emotional awareness.
high.strength: They read emotional cues that many adults miss

medium.headline: Empathy is developing
medium.detail: Your child is starting to notice and care about other people's feelings, especially in obvious situations. They might not always know how to respond, but the awareness is there. Empathy grows with practice and modeling — they're on track.
medium.strength: They notice others' distress — the caring response will catch up with the awareness

low.headline: Still developing perspective-taking
low.detail: Your child is mostly focused on their own experience right now, which is developmentally normal — especially for younger kids. Empathy requires perspective-taking skills that are literally still being wired in their brain.
low.concern: Narrate other people's feelings in everyday moments: "Look, that boy dropped his ice cream — I bet he feels really sad." You're building empathy circuits.

high.headline: Handles setbacks well
high.detail: Your child can tolerate frustration without falling apart. When things don't go their way, they might be disappointed, but they can problem-solve, try again, or move on. This persistence will serve them well in school and life.
high.strength: They can sit with discomfort long enough to find a solution

medium.headline: Getting better at bouncing back
medium.detail: Frustration still knocks your child off course sometimes, but they're getting better at recovering. With some support, they can usually get back to trying. The gap between frustration and recovery is shrinking.
medium.strength: They're building the muscle — each time they recover a little faster is real progress

low.headline: Frustration hits hard
low.detail: When things don't work or aren't fair, your child's frustration overwhelms their ability to cope. Setbacks feel catastrophic in the moment. This isn't stubbornness or manipulation — their window of tolerance for frustration is still narrow.
low.concern: Start with tiny frustration exposures and celebrate recovery: "You were so frustrated, and you tried again anyway. That's really brave."

strong-eq.headline: Your child has strong emotional intelligence
strong-eq.subheadline: They're building an inner world that will serve them for life.
strong-eq.explanation: Across all four dimensions, your child is showing well-developed emotional skills. They can name their feelings, manage their reactions, empathize with others, and handle frustration. This didn't happen by accident — someone is modeling and teaching these skills.
nextSteps: Keep doing what you're doing — talk about emotions, validate feelings, and model self-regulation
Challenge them with slightly harder emotional scenarios (conflict resolution with friends, delayed gratification)
Let them be an emotional leader — they can help siblings or friends navigate feelings
strong-eq.watchOutFor: High emotional intelligence in kids sometimes comes with high sensitivity. Make sure they know it's OK to not fix everyone else's feelings.
strong-eq.encouragement: These skills are a better predictor of life success than IQ. Your child is building the foundation for strong relationships, resilience, and self-awareness.
strong-eq.comparativeContext: Research from the CASEL framework shows that children with strong social-emotional skills perform better academically and have fewer behavioral challenges.

developing-eq.headline: Your child's emotional intelligence is actively developing
developing-eq.subheadline: They've got the building blocks — now it's about practice.
developing-eq.explanation: Your child shows strength in some emotional areas and is still growing in others. This is exactly where most children are — emotional intelligence isn't a switch that flips, it's a set of skills that develop over years with practice and support.
nextSteps: Focus on the domains where they scored lower — small daily practices make a big difference
Name emotions out loud throughout the day, for yourself and for them
Use books, shows, and real-life moments to practice identifying feelings
developing-eq.watchOutFor: Don't overwork the areas where they struggle — emotional learning happens best when kids feel safe, not pressured.
developing-eq.encouragement: The fact that you're paying attention to your child's emotional development puts you ahead of the curve. Most of these skills develop dramatically between ages 4-8 with consistent support.
developing-eq.comparativeContext: Most children in this age range score in the developing range. Emotional intelligence continues to grow well into adulthood.

emerging-eq.headline: Your child's emotional skills are just getting started
emerging-eq.subheadline: This isn't a problem — it's a starting point.
emerging-eq.explanation: Your child is still early in developing the ability to name feelings, manage reactions, and understand others' perspectives. This is very common and not a reflection of your parenting. Every child's emotional development follows its own timeline.
nextSteps: Start with emotion labeling — "You look frustrated" gives them words they don't have yet
Focus on co-regulation: stay calm during their storms, which slowly teaches them to calm themselves
Use simple feelings charts or emotion cards as daily conversation starters
emerging-eq.watchOutFor: If your child is consistently unable to recover from emotional distress or is aggressive/withdrawn in ways that concern you, talk to your pediatrician.
emerging-eq.encouragement: Young children literally don't have the brain wiring for complex emotional skills yet — the prefrontal cortex isn't fully developed until the mid-twenties. What you're doing right now by showing up and trying is building the scaffolding they need.
emerging-eq.comparativeContext: Emotional development varies enormously between children of the same age. Where your child is now says very little about where they'll be in two years.
